title: Brexit: What is happening in the House of Commons on ‘Super Saturday?’
text:
Boris Johnson wants his deal to pass today

Boris Johnson is facing a crunch Commons vote over Brexit in what has been dubbed ‘Super Saturday.’

As the Halloween departure date fast approaches, the stakes are high and today really is make-or-break.

But what is the historic showdown all about?

Parliament is sitting for the first time in 37 years (Picture: AP)

What is ‘Super Saturday?’

The House of Commons is sitting at a weekend for the first time in 37 years in a final bid to break the Brexit deadlock.

The Commons will sit from 9.30am and the Lords will sit from 10am. The first order of business will be a statement from the Prime Minister to update the House after the EU Council summit.

After Mr Johnson’s statement, the Government is expected to move its motion seeking MPs’ approval for a Brexit deal.

MPs have been able to table amendments since Thursday night, and Speaker John Bercow can select as many amendments as he wants, with votes taking place on those before the vote on the Government motion.

Advertisement

Among those include plans to extend the Brexit deadline again to prevent an ‘accidental’ no-deal departure as well as another that would include a second referendum.

The debate on the motion can run until any time on Saturday, and despite what people thought – and perhaps hoped – there is not a 2.30pm cut-off time.

Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay, Prime Minister Boris Johnson, Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, and Michel Barnier, the EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator have agreed a deal (Picture: PA)

Could Boris Johnson get Brexit over the line?

It’s a simple numbers game. There are 650 sitting MPs but the seven Sinn Fein MPs do not take their seats in Westminster and the Speaker and his three deputies do not vote.

Therefore Mr Johnson needs 320 votes for his deal to pass.

The PM has 287 Tory MPs after he dramatically sacked 21 when they voted against him last month to make a no-deal Brexit illegal.

He has been attempting to win them over as well as a number of Labour rebels.

His traditional DUP allies have refused to back him, saying the new deal is a gross betrayal of them and the union.

The SNP, Labour and the Lib Dems alongside other smaller parties have all indicated they will not vote with Mr Johnson.

So far, there are 303 people on board with Mr Johnson and 301 confirmed against.

Eleven do not vote while 35 are still undecided. It really is too close to call.

Jeremy Corbyn will instruct Labour to vote against the deal (Picture: AFP)

What happens if the deal passes?

Advertisement

Advertisement

If the Prime Minister is successful in Westminster, it paves the way for the UK to leave on October 31.

MEPs in the European Parliament still need to approve it.

UK politicians will then need to sit late into the night in order to pass the necessary legislation to make Britain’s EU withdrawal legally enforceable.

The Prime Minister would need to find a further majority for the European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill in order to put Brexit on the statute books.

MEPs would still need to agree to the vote passing (Picture: EPA)

What happens if the deal fails?

If Parliament does not support the deal, Mr Johnson is compelled under the Benn Act to request a further Brexit delay to the end of January.

All 27 EU member states would have to agree to this and could decide a new date.

EU Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker piled the pressure on MPs to back the deal by raising doubts over any further delay to the UK’s departure past October 31.

But European Council President Donald Tusk said if there is a request for an extension he will ‘consult with other member states to see how they react’.

Mr Johnson has said he does not want to ask for an extension, declaring it is ‘no deal or no delay.’

Former Conservative MP Oliver Letwin wants to officially rule out no-deal (Picture: PA)

Could a no-deal Brexit still happen?

Potentially. There are fears that even if Mr Johnson’s deal passes through the House of Commons today, Parliament could run out of time to pass all the necessary legal steps.

Advertisement

Some critics of Boris Johnson suspect he is ‘duping’ MPs into backing him and he will simply run down the clock and leave without an arrangement by the end of the transition period in December 2020.

Trade talks are supposed to happen within this transition period and we could still leave with no-deal if they fail.

Former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin is trying to add an amendment to today’s vote which would withhold approval of the deal unless and until implementing legislation has passed.

This keeps the Benn Act extension in place until all the legal boxes are ticked and would prevent an ‘accidental no-deal departure.’

It’s an important day in the House of Commons (Picture: AFP)

How rare is a Saturday sitting?

The Commons has only sat on four Saturdays since 1939, including on September 2 that year, due to the outbreak of the Second World War.

The last time there was a Saturday sitting was April 3 1982 following the invasion of the Falkland Islands.

MPs also sat on Saturday July 30 1949 in order to finish up business before the summer adjournment as well as on Saturday November 3 1956 due to the Suez crisis.
description: MPs are sitting to debate and vote on Boris Johnson's new Brexit bill that could pave the way for an October 31 EU departure.
